annotation.text:
Major Jackson: Vera, what do you
think is the significance of the
youth being here at this conference?

Vera L. Beatty: Um, I think it's
significant that the youth is here
today to recognize and be able to

Vera L. Beatty: have a discourse with, um, older
writers that are here and people
who are out in the community.

Vera L. Beatty: A lot of people that are here
are teachers as well as writers.

Vera L. Beatty: And I think it's good to have some
type of discourse with the youth that
are out here doing something today
besides it being in kind of like an

Vera L. Beatty: academic setting where it's like peer
and teacher positions or something like
that so they can like Just have an easy
flowing like conversation or whatever.

Major Jackson: Has there been
a lot of dialogue between the
elder literary folk and the young
aspiring writers in your opinion?

Vera L. Beatty: Um, I
actually don't think so.

Vera L. Beatty: No, I think it's, everything has been
actually pretty much respectful and I
was hoping to catch Jabari Asim today,
actually, because he was going to talk

Vera L. Beatty: a little bit about hip hop and I wanted
to hear what he had to say about that,
the younger people and older people also.

Vera L. Beatty: Which is something we were
discussing last night.

Vera L. Beatty: We just had a kind of like free for
all back at the hotel where young
writers and older writers actually

Vera L. Beatty: were reading their work and some
people just came out of curiosity.

Vera L. Beatty: And that was a lot of people's main
concern as to what was going on in terms
of like discourse between and um, critical

Vera L. Beatty: critiquing of these older writers and
what they had done and what we should be
doing now and whatever, things like that.

Major Jackson: Yeah, I thought that
was a very special moment myself, uh,
primarily because it was the first visible
moment in which you did see, uh, these

Major Jackson: young writers who have been reading,
uh, Gwendolyn Brooks, you know, highly
anthologized woman, uh, who have heard
the, the, Older poets who have been on

Major Jackson: the periphery like Kalamu, Yassalam, and
Eskeetore, uh, to, uh, finally engage
them on their work and their times,
you know, the black arts movement.

Major Jackson: And I think on some level, um,
anticipating the need to, uh,
define for them, uh, how poetry

Major Jackson: is going to be received, uh,
aesthetically in the community,
um, functionally in the community.
Major Jackson: And, in their own lives, you know.

Major Jackson: I think it was also good, um,
that they saw these people who are
actually living writers as opposed
to just being like on a page as well.

Vera L. Beatty: And seeing
them be accessible to them, I
thought that was a good thing.
Vera L. Beatty: Right.

Judith Thomas: Well, Dolores, so
happy you could be here today.

Dolores Kendrick: I'm glad
to see you too, Judith.

Judith Thomas: Tell me about the
excitement that you're feeling.

Judith Thomas: about this wonderful conference in
relation to what you yourself have,
um, contributed to the world of poetry.

Dolores Kendrick: Well, I think it's
sort of a milestone of, uh, in terms of
literature in this country because if

Dolores Kendrick: you really think about it, uh, You'll
never get together these many poets,
these prominent poets, these kinds of

Dolores Kendrick: poets, these poets who are involved in
this kind of thinking and movement again
for probably another 30 or 40 years.
Dolores Kendrick: I mean, as we have it today.

Dolores Kendrick: Uh, Sam Allen and I
were talking about that.

Dolores Kendrick: Saying what a celebration, it's really
a celebration when it comes down to it.

Dolores Kendrick: And, uh, it's a privilege to be
here with, with so many, uh, minds.

Dolores Kendrick: With so many people who feel talking
about poetry is normal and natural.

Dolores Kendrick: Because I know in my environment,
no matter, even in some places
in the academia, how do you feel?

Dolores Kendrick: Some places in the academia,
some people are very, very
tender when it comes to poetry.

Dolores Kendrick: Um, so it's nice to be able to talk
with people and be with people.

Dolores Kendrick: And I think it's making a
contribution, not only to this
community, but as it goes, probably,
to the whole world of poetry.
Dolores Kendrick: How do you feel about it?

Judith Thomas: Well, you know, what's
exciting to me is that, um, as I
listen to the reading of the poetry,
and I talk to people like yourself,

Judith Thomas: and you know, I've interacted with
Nikki Giovanni on several occasions,
and of course with Sonia Sanchez.

Judith Thomas: What's, what's so exciting about
today is that, um, I'm seeing
poetry, in a way, become alive.

Judith Thomas: And, um, and it's sort of embodying,
for me, Um, uh, everything that African
Americans have been in the past.

Judith Thomas: the present and what they
will be in the future.

Judith Thomas: So I think that's, you know, what's sort
of, uh, exciting to me about being here.

Judith Thomas: And, you know, and as, uh, as I look
at you and, and I've read a couple
of the things that you've written
and I think what, what has sort of

Judith Thomas: been impressive to me about having
someone like you to dialogue with
is how you use poetry to teach.

Judith Thomas: And I was wondering if you could
speak to that for a few minutes.

Dolores Kendrick: Yeah, I, um, I know
you're not talking about didacticism.
Dolores Kendrick: I know you're not saying that.

Dolores Kendrick: What I try to do is to, is
to define a situation or
people involved in situations.

Dolores Kendrick: And through that, to get the reader
to look At himself or herself.

Dolores Kendrick: In other words, and I'm very involved
in the spiritual nature of man.
Dolores Kendrick: And how our spirits overcome in the end.
Dolores Kendrick: How they survive and overcome in the end.
Dolores Kendrick: Um, that may be a teaching.

Dolores Kendrick: If somebody reads a poem and says, well,
well, I'll give you a good example.

Dolores Kendrick: There was a woman who read from the
Woman of Plums, Peggy and Killing.

Dolores Kendrick: And that's a poem about one of the
slave women who kills her children
rather than have them become slaves.

Dolores Kendrick: Um, this, this is the, you probably know
it, the, the narrative of Margaret Garner.
Dolores Kendrick: And it was based on that narrative.

Dolores Kendrick: And I did a reading in Boston, and after
I finished, this woman came up to me
in tears, and she was a white woman.
Dolores Kendrick: And I said, you must be a mother.
Dolores Kendrick: She said, yes.

Dolores Kendrick: So you see, if poetry can move, uh, people
into a, uh, a finer, a truer recognition
of who they are and themselves, and get

Dolores Kendrick: them to renew themselves in some way, or
spiritually renew themselves in some way.
Dolores Kendrick: That I, I, I think it works.
Dolores Kendrick: And I don't set out to do that.

Dolores Kendrick: Sometimes the poem takes me
there and I just follow it.
Dolores Kendrick: You must have that experience.
Dolores Kendrick: I mean, it simply takes you there.

Dolores Kendrick: And if, and if you don't
follow it, you are rejecting.
Dolores Kendrick: the muse or whatever you want to call it.
Dolores Kendrick: You're rejecting your own creativity.
Dolores Kendrick: But the poem takes me there.

Dolores Kendrick: That's why I get a little worried
sometimes when people start
defining poetry as political poetry
or this poetry or that poetry.
Dolores Kendrick: One goes where the poem takes one.

Dolores Kendrick: And I think even when we talk of Gwendolyn
Brooks, who I think is probably the
finest, the greatest genius of us all,

Dolores Kendrick: uh, her poems simply take you into
yourself and bring you out again whole.

Dolores Kendrick: And it seems to me that's
what I like to see poems do.

Dolores Kendrick: Now, whatever Definition,
people want to give that.
Dolores Kendrick: If it makes them comfortable, fine.
Dolores Kendrick: But I don't think I'm in any of them.

Dolores Kendrick: In fact, Paul Breiman, when he
first printed me, wrote on the
back of my, my little chapbook,
you can't put her in the category.

Dolores Kendrick: And I realized that's
going to get me in trouble.

Dolores Kendrick: I said, since he wrote that, I said,
it's going to get me in trouble.
Dolores Kendrick: But there it is.
Dolores Kendrick: How, how do you see that?
Dolores Kendrick: Do you, do you, do you see poetry?

Dolores Kendrick: People talked this morning
about poetry as political.
Dolores Kendrick: Poetry as a political force.
Dolores Kendrick: Well, what do you think of that?

Judith Thomas: Well, you know, my
response is, is, is pretty simple.

Judith Thomas: It can be a powerful political
force, but I think that you have
to allow it to take you wherever.
Judith Thomas: Yes.

Judith Thomas: And as long as you understand that poetry,
of course, is an art form, and that it
does transcend politics, as it were.

Judith Thomas: But if it takes you there and allows
you to have a deeper understanding,
political situation at that particular
time, then it's done its job.
Judith Thomas: It has worked for you in that context.

Judith Thomas: Um, what struck me today, and I
wondered what you thought about this,
um, was of course, the, uh, speakers,

Judith Thomas: um, uh, allusion to, of course, Ralph
Ellison's work, The Invisible Man.

Judith Thomas: And I've never heard anyone, um, In a
sense, extrapolate from his invisible,
from Ellison's Invisible Man, what he did.

Judith Thomas: And I thought that, uh, when I found
out that I was going to have this chat
with you, I thought I'd love to get

Judith Thomas: your opinion on his, his, uh, analysis
of what the Invisible Man has done
as it speaks to the black community.
Judith Thomas: Or as he spoke to the black community.

Dolores Kendrick: Let me move
into my experience and try to
explain that through my experience.

Dolores Kendrick: When I read Ralph Ellison's The
Invisible Man, I was overwhelmed
by the art of the book.

Dolores Kendrick: Um, some of it leaning on, um,
on, on poetry in many aspects.

Dolores Kendrick: But I was overwhelmed
by the art of the book.

Dolores Kendrick: Until I went back, until I had
an experience myself, in which I
discovered what being made invisible is.

Dolores Kendrick: And that is through working in a
largely white institution, where if
you become something other than what

Dolores Kendrick: you are supposed to become, there
is a way of making you invisible.

Dolores Kendrick: As a woman in a male world, There is a way
of making you invisible, and it doesn't
always come from the white community.

Dolores Kendrick: It can come from the black
community, which Ellison tells us
about in a few of those chapters.
Judith Thomas: Yes, it does.

Dolores Kendrick: Uh, I, I think what
Ellison did for me was to give me a
whole new experience of what this term

Dolores Kendrick: invisible means and how it relates to me,
not only, not only as a woman, an African
American movement, but as a human being.

Dolores Kendrick: Because no human being
should be made invisible.
Judith Thomas: Absolutely.

Dolores Kendrick: And I think he makes
that statement very, very powerfully.

Dolores Kendrick: Because remember, in The Visible
Man, he, he gets, he gets
blown away by his own people.
Dolores Kendrick: That's right.
Dolores Kendrick: Half the time.
Dolores Kendrick: So, I, I, I don't know whether,

Judith Thomas: What message, can
you then translate that into the
message for, to, for the, for
the contemporary black community?
Judith Thomas: What is it that we need to do?

Judith Thomas: It's obvious that, you know, we meet
in some way the criteria for middle
classness, whatever that means.

Judith Thomas: How can we use what Ralph Ellison tells
us in The Invisible Man and the poetry
of some of the people who are here

Judith Thomas: today, as well as your own writing,
to connect with the black community?
Judith Thomas: How can we do that?

Dolores Kendrick: I think, first
of all, we, and I sound like I know
what I'm talking about, don't I?

Dolores Kendrick: I, I got a lot, a lot of living
to do before I could even back
up this answer I'm gonna give.

Dolores Kendrick: But I, I think, first of all, we have
to learn how to empower ourselves.

Dolores Kendrick: And we empower ourselves by knowing our
history, by, uh, networking, by bonding.

Dolores Kendrick: Uh, there is, there is so much,
so much Out here, that allows
us to separate from each other.

Dolores Kendrick: For, for, for reasons,
for one reason or another.

Dolores Kendrick: And to allow what energies there are
out here that wants, that want to
see us separated and disinherited
and invisible and unempowered.

Dolores Kendrick: These, these energies come in
and do it very beautifully.

Dolores Kendrick: Take, uh, Toni Morrison's
getting the Nobel.
Dolores Kendrick: Right.

Dolores Kendrick: And the, the backlash that came from
her contemporary black, uh, uh, writers.

Judith Thomas: Why do
you suppose that was?

Dolores Kendrick: But, I think
it's, my mother used to have a
phrase for that, if I dare say it.
Judith Thomas: Yeah, please tell us.

Dolores Kendrick: My mother
used to say crabs in a barrel.

Dolores Kendrick: She used to say that we have not
gotten away from the plantation,
because in the plantation the
master used to get the crabs.

Dolores Kendrick: People, some people to spy on other
people and let them know what's going
on and they, they were able to keep

Dolores Kendrick: their, uh, faith or keep themselves
together was a desperate, desperate move.

Dolores Kendrick: Um, to some degree, we, some of us may
still be there because we are being,
uh, usurped or by the white community
that does not want to see us empowered.

Dolores Kendrick: After all, if a black person
receives a Nobel, that's a,
that's empowerment, period.
Dolores Kendrick: That's empowerment.

Dolores Kendrick: I mean, probably the greatest
you can get in literature.

Dolores Kendrick: And, and, if you can find people
out here who are going to give
a certain backlash, and And sort
of make that person invisible.

Dolores Kendrick: Think of that, making a Nobel
Prize winner invisible and using
black people in order to do it.

Dolores Kendrick: And I, I don't know why we don't see
through that except that our need
to be noticed, our need to become
visible is so great that we will buy

Dolores Kendrick: into that in order to make another
Part of ourselves, and ourselves
would be another person, invisible.

Dolores Kendrick: I think we've got a lot to learn, to
answer your question, that we have to
go into the schools, teach the children,

Dolores Kendrick: make the children proud of their heritage,
stop them from, you know, Toni Morrison
said that we all wanted to forget slavery.

Dolores Kendrick: She said, um, blacks wanted to forget it
because they wanted to put it behind us.

Dolores Kendrick: Uh, whites wanted to forget
it because of the grief.

Dolores Kendrick: And she made the statement,
I think, in Time Magazine.

Dolores Kendrick: She says she thinks we
all have national amnesia.
Dolores Kendrick: Well, it's time we're done with that.

Dolores Kendrick: And we begin to do what the Jews
have done with the Holocaust.

Dolores Kendrick: And let the world know that
we are proud of what we did.

Dolores Kendrick: We, we rose up from one of the
first holocausts in this country.
Dolores Kendrick: And, and became a very strong Powerful.
Dolores Kendrick: Yes, powerful people.

Dolores Kendrick: And I think we have to
teach our children that.
Dolores Kendrick: Teach our children to be proud of that.
Dolores Kendrick: Teach them how to network.
Dolores Kendrick: You know, we say brother and sister.
Dolores Kendrick: But sometimes we don't really mean that.

Dolores Kendrick: And, and, and try to get our, our,
our kids in a positive view of
themselves, to like themselves, to

Dolores Kendrick: love themselves, through their history,
and through other forms of education.

Judith Thomas: And, and of
course through, through poetry.
Dolores Kendrick: Exactly.
Dolores Kendrick: Through poetry they can do that.

Dolores Kendrick: I think you've heard, I don't know,
have you heard that, uh, Judith,
that there are many young people
who don't know of, of James Baldwin?
Judith Thomas: I live that every day.
Judith Thomas: I live it every day.
Judith Thomas: Yeah.

Judith Thomas: Historically black institution and I'm
amazed at the number of young black men
and women who have not had any exposure
To black art as it were in any form.
Dolores Kendrick: Absolutely.

Judith Thomas: And that's why
of course this Celebration you
and I are experiencing today.
Judith Thomas: It's so important.

Judith Thomas: It's so important In fact that I was
going to ask you where you were on
how one could infuse This whole black
literature experience into the existing

Judith Thomas: curricula in both the public or in the
private, public and parochial schools that
would allow not only black young men and

Judith Thomas: women to become empowered through their
literature, but would allow our white
brothers and sisters and Asian brothers

Judith Thomas: and sisters and Latino brothers and
sisters to understand the African American
experience through their literature.
Judith Thomas: Poetry.
Judith Thomas: Yes.

Judith Thomas: And I, and I wondered with your experience
at Philip Exeter, which is one of the
finest, uh, uh, uh, private schools in
the country, Uh, did, were you able to use

Judith Thomas: poetry as a vehicle through which and by
which your young students could then, in
a sense, experience, um, black culture?

Dolores Kendrick: A small
example, Gwendolyn Brooks poem
of the life of Lincoln West.

Dolores Kendrick: That is an extraordinary poem about
this young kid who is, and when
Gwen reads it, she said he was ugly.
Dolores Kendrick: She really uses that word, ugly.

Dolores Kendrick: She reads this wonderful poem
about this young kid who is ugly
and, uh, whom everybody rejects.
Dolores Kendrick: And, and she goes through it all.

Dolores Kendrick: The mother, the teacher,
everybody rejects him.

Dolores Kendrick: The teacher takes her to a,
takes him to a, I mean the mother
takes him to a film one day.
Dolores Kendrick: And this white man across the street.

Dolores Kendrick: The way he says to the, aloud
to his girlfriend, Look!
Dolores Kendrick: That's a real one.
Dolores Kendrick: A real one.
Dolores Kendrick: Look at the nappy hair.
Dolores Kendrick: That's an original.

Dolores Kendrick: And at the end of the poem, the
young boy says, works out proudly,
he takes that insult and, and
turns it into a celebration.
Dolores Kendrick: And he says, I am an original.

Dolores Kendrick: We read that at Exeter and I said, you
know, we talked about what is an original.

Dolores Kendrick: We talk about all the original
clothes they buy, all the
money these clothes talk.
Dolores Kendrick: What does original mean?

Dolores Kendrick: Because basically, I'm ta you're talking
to a bunch of kids, even though they
are well off and whatnot, are having

Dolores Kendrick: the same kind of traumatic problems
that most kids out here are having.

Dolores Kendrick: But here they see through a black
child, and this black child's
willingness to celebrate himself,
how they can celebrate themselves.

Dolores Kendrick: That because that they're
having almost the same problems.

Dolores Kendrick: And when that begins to connect,
they It connects beautifully,
because they say, Ah, a black kid
is teaching me this, you know.

Dolores Kendrick: And, and, or a black
woman is teaching me this.

Dolores Kendrick: Believe me, Gwen became very
popular after that poem was taken,
uh, uh, taught so many times.
Dolores Kendrick: She had been popular.

Dolores Kendrick: But what I'm saying is that you
can use, as your question implies,
does that make sense to you?
Judith Thomas: Yes, it does.
Judith Thomas: Very much so.

Judith Thomas: And I just want to say it was
so fun chatting with you today.

Judith Thomas: And maybe you and I can continue
this conversation another time.
Dolores Kendrick: I hope so, Julie.
Dolores Kendrick: We have to do that.
Dolores Kendrick: Yes.

Sandra Govan: Pinky, I'd like to
ask you a variant on the question
you ask in freshman composition

Sandra Govan: classes, and that is, when and why
and how did you start writing poetry?

Pinkie Gordon Lane: How
did I start writing poetry?

Pinkie Gordon Lane: Uh, I started writing poetry, I really
came to poetry late in life because
I was writing fiction although I
hadn't gotten anything published.

Pinkie Gordon Lane: But I had thought I wanted
to be a fiction writer.

Pinkie Gordon Lane: And then I discovered the, uh,
person to whom this conference is
dedicated, uh, Gwendolyn Brooks.

Pinkie Gordon Lane: Uh, uh, I read her first book
of poetry, Speed and Bronx, many
years after it was published.
Pinkie Gordon Lane: And I said, gee, that's what I want to do.

Pinkie Gordon Lane: And I started writing poetry
and I found out my temperament
was more suited to that.

Pinkie Gordon Lane: And I've been really dedicating all of
my time now to writing poetry rather
than, uh, venturing off into other media.
Sandra Govan: Okay.

Pinkie Gordon Lane: But she
was my, she was really my
inspiration, Gwendolyn Brooks.
Pinkie Gordon Lane: Wonderful woman.
Pinkie Gordon Lane: I love her.

Sandra Govan: And she's from
my city too, so I do too.
Sandra Govan: Share that love.

Sandra Govan: But you say your
temperament was more suited.
Sandra Govan: Can you push that for me a little bit?
Pinkie Gordon Lane: All right.

Pinkie Gordon Lane: I suppose I was thinking, not only
because I can deal with a poem,
It's more, it's more confined.
Pinkie Gordon Lane: It's more condensed.

Pinkie Gordon Lane: Uh, I can write it while I'm
sitting in the automobile.

Pinkie Gordon Lane: Or I can write it as I have done,
uh, between classes in my office.

Pinkie Gordon Lane: At that time I was teaching
at Southern University.

Pinkie Gordon Lane: And I, I think as a fiction writer
you'd have to be much more disciplined
in doing something every day.

Pinkie Gordon Lane: If you're gonna, if you're, if
you're Writing a novel, for example.

Pinkie Gordon Lane: And I just never, I taught
for many, many years.
Pinkie Gordon Lane: And my students were my priority.

Pinkie Gordon Lane: And I just didn't have time to sit
down and say I'm going to devote four
hours or eight hours a day to that.

Pinkie Gordon Lane: But also because I, uh, got a kind
of an emotional, or a release,
and a feel for writing a poem.

Pinkie Gordon Lane: I always felt good when
a poem was finished.
Pinkie Gordon Lane: You see?

Pinkie Gordon Lane: And so I suppose that's what I mean when I
say my temperament was more suited to it.

Pinkie Gordon Lane: Uh, it seemed to, to, uh, satisfy
some inner thing inside of me
that I, uh, evidently wanted
to let out, wanted to surface.

Sandra Govan: Okay, that, that
brings to mind two questions for me.
Sandra Govan: Um, the first has to do with form.

Sandra Govan: You said that the poetry is
really brief and it allowed you
to work in short time spans.
Sandra Govan: So, did you, do you do a lot of revising?

Sandra Govan: Or, um, in part two of that,
after revision, is that the form
of your poetry seems to be the
short, clipped kinds of lines.

Pinkie Gordon Lane: Uh, I, uh,
don't do a lot of revising.

Pinkie Gordon Lane: Depends on what you mean a lot,
because it's a relative term.
Pinkie Gordon Lane: Uh, but I do do some revising.

Pinkie Gordon Lane: And whenever I do revise, it's
always a matter of cutting
down, sharpening the image.
Pinkie Gordon Lane: You see, I'm an imagist.
Pinkie Gordon Lane: Okay.

Pinkie Gordon Lane: I'm very much concerned with
the metaphor and the way
something is said, the language.

Pinkie Gordon Lane: Uh, as well as the content
of what you have to say.

Pinkie Gordon Lane: And, uh, when I'm first writing,
Of course, I'm just putting down
everything that comes into my head as
fast as I can before I lose the idea.
Pinkie Gordon Lane: Then I begin to cut down.
Pinkie Gordon Lane: I begin to look at the imagery.
Pinkie Gordon Lane: I begin to look at the words.
Pinkie Gordon Lane: Uh, the concise meaning of words.
Pinkie Gordon Lane: Uh, is the image a clich?
Pinkie Gordon Lane: Uh, is it, uh, does it have originality?
Pinkie Gordon Lane: What kind of power does it have?

Pinkie Gordon Lane: So when I revise, I'm always
looking for, I'm revising in
terms of technique and style.
Pinkie Gordon Lane: I've already said what I want to say.

Pinkie Gordon Lane: You know, the thought is there, but I'm
concerned with then the use of language.

Sandra Govan: Alright, and the thought
seems to be, I, I was looking at
some of your poems before I came to
the conference and um, there's a new

Sandra Govan: volume out that our library happened
to have and I cannot call the name of
it, right at the, Girl at the Window.
Sandra Govan: Girl at it is, Girl at the Window.

Sandra Govan: And I was, as I was reading those poems, I
noticed that a lot of them deal with love
and, Pain and some vivid recollections
intermixed with ruined lives.
Sandra Govan: Pain intermixed with ruined lives.
Sandra Govan: Where is that coming from?

Pinkie Gordon Lane: You know, uh,
some of the poems in that book go back
quite a long way because some of them

Pinkie Gordon Lane: are poems that had been previously
published and, uh, of course some of
them, uh, a number of them are new poems.

Pinkie Gordon Lane: So it's a kind of a documentary of my
life and my emotional life, my psychic
life all, uh, through, over several years.
Pinkie Gordon Lane: Uh, I don't feel pain anymore.
Pinkie Gordon Lane: I'm a happy person.

Pinkie Gordon Lane: But, you know, we, we, uh, we do have
to struggle, uh, to know ourselves and
what our identity, uh, happens to be.

Pinkie Gordon Lane: And I suppose that through those
years I was, I was looking for my,
who, who really is Pinkie Lane.
Pinkie Gordon Lane: And so this, uh, a lot of it was pain.
Pinkie Gordon Lane: You see, a lot of it was pain.

Pinkie Gordon Lane: Because I had a, really had a,
I had a struggling childhood.

Pinkie Gordon Lane: My father was an alcoholic and,
uh, it was a dysfunctional family.

Pinkie Gordon Lane: I was dealing with this years
after he had died, you see.

Pinkie Gordon Lane: I came to terms with it, but I think
my poetry helped me to do that.

Sandra Govan: Because a section in the
poem, To Your Father, is the one that
really I was thinking about the most.
Pinkie Gordon Lane: Yes.

Sandra Govan: When you talk
about divorcing your father.
